awd_titl_txt: NSF/DMR-BSF: The Effects of Configurational Disorder on Polaron Transport
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical Abstract: Oxides are well known as materials with low electronic conductivity. But upon closer examination, there is a great deal of variability in their ability to conduct charge, and much of this is unexplained. For instance, in cobalt manganese oxides the conductivity can increase up to 10 times depending on the cobalt to manganese ratio. The existing theories are accurate when there are only two components, for instance, just cobalt and oxygen, but when a third component is included, the theories break down. In this project, the team is investigating a fundamental question of oxides: how does atomic disorder affect conductivity in oxides. By elucidating these mechanisms, the team is opening up new avenues to tailor the conductivity in oxides, important for applications that rely on the insulating properties of oxides, as in semiconductor transistors, or for applications that could benefit from increased conductivity, as in batteries and fuel cells. To disseminate and promote science to the public the team is creating a website with on-line training videos to strengthen international science outreach and the US-Israel partnership using science for peaceful purposes, and the team is designing a module on electronic conductivity in oxides for Lending Library Experiments. The kit aligns with specific Next Generation Science Standards and uses exploratory hands-on activities to help experiential learning.

Technical Abstract: The purpose of this work is to investigate a fundamental question in ternary oxides: how do charge carriers move through a spinel crystal lattice when there is more than one type of cation. It is known that the most prominent mechanism of charge transport in oxides is through hopping that follows the polaron models. But the polaron hopping models are too crude to account for the configurational differences that occur in ternary transition metal spinels, where the two different cation types can exhibit large degrees of disorder between the two cation lattice sites and possess a variety of oxidation states. As a consequence, the effects of cation disorder and cation oxidation states on electronic conductivity has not been well-described in multinary spinels. To investigate this question the team is synthesizing ternary oxide spinels, characterizing the cation disorder, and correlating the disorder with the electronic transport. The team is using x-ray emission spectroscopy, high-angle annular dark-field imaging, and electron energy loss spectroscopy to determine site occupancy, oxidation states, and local atomic segregation. The experimental results are coupled with theory to understand the mechanisms and outline a global model for transport. The team is using DFT-type calculations with periodic and non-periodic boundary conditions, and is analyzing charge transport characteristics related to hopping mechanisms in oxide materials to determine if the charge carriers lie on delocalized (overlapping) or localized states for specific cation distributions and concentrations. Understanding the fundamental mechanisms of polarons is a grand challenge for fields including molecular architectures, and electrical energy storage, where details of charge transport in poor electron-conductor materials could have a large impact. Understanding the relationship between cation configurational disorder and polaron hopping could lead to designer oxides with tailored properties. The team is promoting science to the public by creating a website with on-line training videos for international science outreach and to strengthen the US-Israel partnership using science for peaceful purposes, and designing an experiment on electronic conductivity in oxides for Lending Library Experiments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The intellectual merit of our project was centered around the development of new insights into the charge transport mechanism in the ternary spinel oxide system. Understanding the mechanism of charge transport in complex oxides will enable us to tailor various materials properties that are useful for technology and applications, such as electronic and electrochemical processes in nanoparticles and thin film oxides. One of our strongest motivations is to understand the limitations of conventional small polaron nearest neighbor hopping model, developed in the 1960s. In complex systems such as ternary spinels, it turns out that there are several different pathways for polaron hopping and these choices for multiple pathways are not captured in the conventional small polaron hopping model. 

To address this issue, we developed suitable theoretical explanations to estimate the configurational disorder of the cations in the spinel structure and analyzed different stoichiometries of cobalt manganese oxide thin films using advanced X-ray synchrotron techniques. Extracting cationic site occupations from the spinel system gave us insight to understand how concentrations of polaron hopping pairs correlate to electronic properties in the system. Beyond the cationic information, understanding how the defects from anions affect the charge transport mechanism and tune the electrical properties in the system will be the next step to our future research. This fundamental knowledge of the spinel structure and its properties will be a key factor to devise future applications such as charge storage capacity of batteries or memristors. Over the course of the award, we achieved the following key outcomes and findings. First, we employed the ternary CoxMn3-xO4 spinel system to identify relationships between electronic properties and cation site occupation, based on the octahedral site, donor-acceptor formalization described in the polaron hopping models. We found out that Mn4+/Mn3+ pairs are the dominant active species and the origin of the stoichiometry-dependent behavior for polaron charge transport. This result serves as a foundation for comprehending and improving charge transfer for higher order spinels. Additionally, we used iron-based ternary MnxFe3-xO4 spinel oxide grown by molecular beam epitaxy which is advantageous to achieve high purity and crystalline structures. We revised the conventional small-polaron hopping model by introducing new parameters to elaborate percolation, cross-hopping, and polaron-distribution and explained the transport mechanism by delineation the difference in the transport along the Fe versus the Mn cation pathways. 

Beyond the fundamental studies, we also studied spinels in electrochemical energy storage applications (e.g., supercapacitors and Li-ion batteries). We focused on strain control and employed Fe3O4@MnFe2O4 (core@shell) nanoparticles with varying shell thickness to control the lattice strain. All electrochemical performance such as energy density, power density, and specific capacitance in the strained spinel system show advanced performance compared to the unstrained spinel system. This establishes a foundation for the unique strain engineering method for creating high-performance energy storage devices.

 

During the research process, we discovered inventive methodologies and X-ray characterization to determine cation site occupation. The general method for extracting the cation site information crystal structure was extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS). However, the characterization technique was limited to only site occupation, and showed high errors for certain stoichiometries. To resolve the issues, we employed X-ray emission spectroscopy (XES) that can provide not only the site occupation formation like EXAFS, but it also provides additional information on the oxidation states of the cations at each site. The technique is reliable and powerful because we can use the oxidation state sensitive Kꞵ1,3 peak. We compared those two different X-ray techniques and concluded that XES is much more accurate than EXAFS, and therefore more suitable than EXAFS to extract site occupation in the spinel crystal structures. 

As a result of our work, we authored five peer-reviewed articles in prestigious journals and presented nine papers at conferences. As of fall 2003, these publications have received 71 citations, indicating their impact in the academic community.
